snippet.textDisplay: At first I was excited about this video and how it would probably give good consumer advice. But I feel a couple of things were left out. How does Alyx play on a Vive Pro? (there was only this cryptic reference saying we should not watch his Vive Pro review? Not everyone watches all your videos and knows what you mean.) How much value does a wireless VR headset give for the Alyx experience and which headsets have that option? What about Alyx on the Vive Cosmos?

snippet.textDisplay: I am really interested in Alyx and was wondering about hardware a lot recently. As someone who plays mainly strategy games (and minecraft), I dont really worry about graphics that much, I focus on cpu and ram more. My pc is a reasonable build from 2016 (i5 6600k on 4,3ghz and r9 fury nitro), but its getting old, when it comes to games. I have plans to upgrade (or maybe just build an entirely new pc) somewhere around the end of 2020 to the mid 2021. And I also wanted to get into vr. Seeing that gpu isnt really that much for hl alyx is good news, I wont have to spend too much on it, considering I wouldnt use it elsewhere anyway. Now for vr kit - index controllers is a must have. All fingers tracking seems so much better then other solutions. For the headseat - I dont really know. Index is impressive, but without expensive gpu I wouldnt need it anyway, right? Vive or oculus should be just fine in this case
snippet.textOriginal: I am really interested in Alyx and was wondering about hardware a lot recently. As someone who plays mainly strategy games (and minecraft), I dont really worry about graphics that much, I focus on cpu and ram more. I have plans to upgrade (or maybe just build an entirely new pc) somewhere around the end of 2020 to the mid 2021. And I also wanted to get into vr. Seeing that gpu isnt really that much for hl alyx is good news, I wont have to spend too much on it, considering I wouldnt use it elsewhere anyway. Now for vr kit - index controllers is a must have. All fingers tracking seems so much better then other solutions. For the headseat - I dont really know. Index is impressive, but without expensive gpu I wouldnt need it anyway, right? Vive or oculus should be just fine in this case

snippet.textDisplay: My answer is: 0 $. I have VR, but i use it  for sim racing / racing games, if it's supported. Otherwise, VR, as it is now, must die. It's not easy to setup and it has lots of troubleshooting. Fuck VR, fuck valve and whoever decided that this game needs to be vr only.
snippet.textOriginal: My answer is: 0 $. I have VR, but i use it  for sim racing / racing games, if it's supported. Otherwise, VR, as it is now, must die. It's not easy to setup and it has lots of troubleshooting. Fuck VR, fuck valve and whoever decided that this game needs to be vr only.

snippet.textDisplay: you missed a key point of difference,  wile spending more on the index for better controllers you loose out on the abillity to use the oculus store, buy going downt the rift s route youd have access to both oculus store and steam,  yes i get that this is only in relation to hl alyx but lets face it you have to  play somthing else at some point an if im honest for me at least it would be better to have access to more content and games than a better controller, add to the fact that if you look hard enough there are accessories out there for the oculus controllers to alow you to release without droping them so then your only leaft with having to use your bottom 3 fingers off one button but a nice compromise when you consider pricing, im not sure how gfx pricing works over there but in UK an rtx2070 super is around £500 and a rx5700xt is around £340 the rift s is  £399 vs the quest bundle at £919 an while alyx is then free that is still a hefty jump for most people, personly id recomend the oculus and rx5700xt putting you overly at £739 plus £40-£46 for alyx, especially since it dont use ray tracing, an i aint saying this cos i got an rx5700xt an am some sort of fanboy cos im still running with a gtx1070 but without being sponcered buy any particular brand ect you cant deny the vale for money option especially when you factor in all the vr headset costs
snippet.textOriginal: you missed a key point of difference,  wile spending more on the index for better controllers you loose out on the abillity to use the oculus store, buy going downt the rift s route youd have access to both oculus store and steam,  yes i get that this is only in relation to hl alyx but lets face it you have to  play somthing else at some point an if im honest for me at least it would be better to have access to more content and games than a better controller, add to the fact that if you look hard enough there are accessories out there for the oculus controllers to alow you to release without droping them so then your only leaft with having to use your bottom 3 fingers off one button but a nice compromise when you consider pricing, im not sure how gfx pricing works over there but in UK an rtx2070 super is around £500 and a rx5700xt is around £340 the rift s is  £399 vs the quest bundle at £919 an while alyx is then free that is still a hefty jump for most people, personly id recomend the oculus and rx5700xt putting you overly at £739 plus £40-£46 for alyx, especially since it dont use ray tracing, an i aint saying this cos i got an rx5700xt an am some sort of fanboy cos im still running with a gtx1070 but without being sponcered buy any particular brand ect you cant deny the vale for money option especially when you factor in all the vr headset costs

snippet.textDisplay: Small tip: do “not” use screen mirroring with VR games that already mirror its output (spectator mode) together with screen recording (letting the screen mirror 3-7 times (yea this causes huge lag or even disconnects for obvious reasons on low end systems)
snippet.textOriginal: Small tip: do “not” use screen mirroring with VR games that already mirror its output (spectator mode) together with screen recording (letting the screen mirror 3-7 times (yea this causes huge lag or even disconnects for obvious reasons on low end systems)

snippet.textDisplay: I have the CableCreation Active USB Extension Cable as well. I found that the Oculus link to my Quest using the extender and the Anker 3ft USB 3.0 A-C cable was inferior to the Anker 10ft USB 3.0 A-C cable. The 10ft plays Alyx on low settings mostly smooth with my 8 year old i5 3570k (OC 4.2GHz) and a 970 GTX. Just bought it today and enjoyed 50-72 fps most of the time. It got even better when I overclocked the GPU by 400MHz for the RAM and 50MHz for the GPU. Best quarantine surprise thus far!
snippet.textOriginal: I have the CableCreation Active USB Extension Cable as well. I found that the Oculus link to my Quest using the extender and the Anker 3ft USB 3.0 A-C cable was inferior to the Anker 10ft USB 3.0 A-C cable. The 10ft plays Alyx on low settings mostly smooth with my 8 year old i5 3570k (OC 4.2GHz) and a 970 GTX. Just bought it today and enjoyed 50-72 fps most of the time. It got even better when I overclocked the GPU by 400MHz for the RAM and 50MHz for the GPU. Best quarantine surprise thus far!

snippet.textDisplay: Technically the 2070 Super is only slightly higher performance than a 1080, just with raytracing as well; that way any games you have that prefer this will look better for it.  Fundamentally, however, better GPUs just handle more graphics post-processing faster.  Out of curiousity, I would like to know what Valve considers necessary hardware for clean, "Ultra" settings.
snippet.textOriginal: Technically the 2070 Super is only slightly higher performance than a 1080, just with raytracing as well; that way any games you have that prefer this will look better for it.  Fundamentally, however, better GPUs just handle more graphics post-processing faster.  Out of curiousity, I would like to know what Valve considers necessary hardware for clean, "Ultra" settings.

snippet.textDisplay: From being an early VR adopter, I can tell you the main thing you want more GPU power for is super-sampling. Any game with fine lines or text will REALLY benefit from upgrading the render resolution.
snippet.textOriginal: From being an early VR adopter, I can tell you the main thing you want more GPU power for is super-sampling. Any game with fine lines or text will REALLY benefit from upgrading the render resolution.

snippet.textDisplay: you said facebook doesn't care about oculus' products on steam. Well I wish that was right, they do care, but they care in the opposite way, they are trying to fight it, they don't want to forbid it so people don't rebel against oculus, so they are finding other ways, like purpouselly introducing bugs, forcing people to enable outside sources in settings, so people who aren't really into tech think they can't do it, when you are in steamvr, and if you are using oculus dash, it'll constantly give you pop-up to close it etc. all in all they don't want you on steamVR, not that they don't care

snippet.textDisplay: Well, my bottleneck is not the GPU (RTX 2060) nor headset (Rift S), but my 4 year old lowest tier i5. 6400 to be exact. Those specs run games like Beat Saber just fine, but for Alyx my CPU just doesn't meet the requirements. I already had enough problems with Fallout 4 to refund it... though that's Fallout 4, everyone knows how well this game is programmed.
snippet.textOriginal: Well, my bottleneck is not the GPU (RTX 2060) nor headset (Rift S), but my 4 year old lowest tier i5. 6400 to be exact. snippet.textDisplay:
"Realistically, this doesn't look THAT much better than Half-Life 2."


I've been saying for YEARS that I don't see a huge qualitative difference between 2004's HL2 and modern titles.


If I were to put them side by side, sure. But HL2 doesn't look dated to me. I'd say that the difference between 1998 and 2004's HL games is MASSIVE, but the difference between HL2 and any 2018/19 title is just not objectively that much to me.
snippet.textOriginal:
"Realistically, this doesn't look THAT much better than Half-Life 2."


I've been saying for YEARS that I don't see a huge qualitative difference between 2004's HL2 and modern titles.


If I were to put them side by side, sure. But HL2 doesn't look dated to me. I'd say that the difference between 1998 and 2004's HL games is MASSIVE, but the difference between HL2 and any 2018/19 title is just not objectively that much to me.

snippet.textDisplay: It is impressive how well the game looks and performs on modest PCs. But Valve does a lot of dynamic visual quality scaling in their VR applications, so low settings on the 2080ti is not representative of low settings on gtx 970 for example. Dropping settings on the 2080ti is an easy way to do a quick side by side comparison, but in this case I think it is misleading.
snippet.textOriginal: It is impressive how well the game looks and performs on modest PCs. But Valve does a lot of dynamic visual quality scaling in their VR applications, so low settings on the 2080ti is not representative of low settings on gtx 970 for example. Dropping settings on the 2080ti is an easy way to do a quick side by side comparison, but in this case I think it is misleading.

snippet.textDisplay:
I Really do like linus vídeos, but talking shit about Alyx or "Generations behind Graphics", im sorry linus, but you have all to you given for free, you have games given for free, all for free… and i know its your job, but hey, u're rich, we're not, we apreciate what you can't no more, seriously, all i see in ur channel is HIGH TIER Computer stuff… Mid range, and low budget cards or cpus, or headsets, are not the best, but for that goes the name LOW or Tight Budget…
Don't you ever talk shit about this game again, Most AWESOME and Best Game on VR So far, and i've tested a bunch… but it's like you do "shadow" discriminatory comments… like you wanna call people broke, or poor, but you dont do it for the sake of ur company, and Youtube $$$, but we can see that u want to do it bad.

Anyways, im starting to disliking ur content, the more the time goes on.

ALYX IS LIFE

I'll try it one day...when I upgrade my CPU...and VGA...and get a headset.

snippet.textDisplay:
You don't think the jump from the physics and graphics of the first Source engine to Source 2 and Alyx is big? Do you really hate Valve that much to just flat out lie? The effect the Source engine had on gaming alone, never mind the comparison between GoldSRC and Source, should have you jumping up and down for how revolutionary this new tech will be for not just VR but gaming in general.
What a sleight to both the quality of HL2, which does hold up, and the work the devs have put into Source2!
snippet.textOriginal:
You don't think the jump from the physics and graphics of the first Source engine to Source 2 and Alyx is big? Do you really hate Valve that much to just flat out lie? The effect the Source engine had on gaming alone, never mind the comparison between GoldSRC and Source, should have you jumping up and down for how revolutionary this new tech will be for not just VR but gaming in general.
What a sleight to both the quality of HL2, which does hold up, and the work the devs have put into Source2!

snippet.textDisplay: I was a DK1 and DK2 early adopter back in the day but the 1080P res was so low and disappointing that i still haven't bought a new headset since.
